Unnamed: 6:
Description: Emissions related to estimated water consumption from offices that QBE operates. Water bills are generally paid by the building landlords and on-charged to tenants through lease payments. 

QBE estimated water usage and related emissions as follows:
Estimated water consumption per FTE in each country = actual water usage of one office where actual data is available / FTE in that office.
Country water usage = estimated water consumption x FTE per country
Country/region water emissions = kL of water x DEFRA water supply and treatment emission factor.

Scope: 
Group consolidated entities. Excluding associates/joint venture where QBE does not have operational control.

Unit:
Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying unit: kL of water.

Description: Emissions related to air business travel by travel class (economy, premium economy, business class or first class) and by travel type (short haul or long haul). Travel data includes business travel by employees and policyholders as part of their insurance claims related to the relevant insurance product purchased. Travel data is sourced from the travel management company that centrally manages each division's travel (mainly Australia, UK/Europe and North America). For small NZ, Asia and Pacific countries, travel data is obtained through the countryÃ¢ÂÂs own air travel records.

Emissions factors applied to passenger KM air travelled are sourced from UK DEFRAÃ¢ÂÂs required distance uplift and exclude radiative forcing due to the significant scientific uncertainty surrounding the quantification of the effect of radiative forcing.

The UK DEFRA emission factors are released annually to incorporate updated air travel assumptions. In 2023, due to reduced passenger numbers during the COVID-19 pandemic, DEFRAÃ¢ÂÂs air travel emission factors for short-haul and long-haul flights have increased by 21% and 35% respectively. Anticipating a return to pre-COVID passenger numbers, it is not considered appropriate to apply the 2023 DEFRA factors, based on pandemic-period travel data, to calculate emissions for the organisations 2023 travel activity. 

This report maintains consistency by using the 2022 UK DEFRA factors against the 2023 passenger kilometres for comparability with previous years. The impact of using the 2023 UK DEFRA factors would be an increase in the GHG emissions for business travel of 2,472 tCO2, keeping all other inputs constant.

Scope: Group consolidated entities. Excluding associates/joint venture where QBE does not have operational control.

Unit:
Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying unit: KM air travel.

Unnamed: 4: Business travel Ã¢ÂÂ car hire and taxi
Unnamed: 6:
Description: Emissions related to car hire and taxi business travel by employees and policyholders as part of their policy claims. Car hire KM travelled data is sourced from third party car hire company reports. Taxi data is sourced from cab charges/taxi claims booked in the general ledger, and the cost is divided by average taxi cost per KM travelled, to derive estimated KM travelled by taxi. The average taxi cost per KM is estimated by each country based on their knowledge of average taxi cost per KM relevant to their country. 

Emissions are measured by:
KM travelled from car hire and taxi x DEFRA emissions factor for an average car with unknown fuel source.

Scope: 
Group consolidated entities. Excluding associates/joint venture where QBE does not have operational control.
Car Hire and Taxis are used by major divisions: Australia, UK/Europe and North America.
Small countries such NZ, Asia and Pacific have little or no car hire and taxi activities.

Unit:
Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying unit: KM travelled

Unnamed: 4: Business travel Ã¢ÂÂ rail and bus travel
Unnamed: 6:
Description: Emissions related to rail and bus business travel by employees. Only UK/Europe used rail and bus as an alternative to air business travel due to the close proximity of European countries. Rail and bus travel data is sourced from the UK travel management company which manages both UK and Europe air, bus and rail travel.

Emissions are estimated using the following formula:
KM travelled from rail and bus x DEFRA emissions factor for rail and bus.

Scope: 
Group consolidated entities. Excluding associates/joint venture where QBE does not have operational control.
Only UK/Europe used rail and bus as alternative to air travel due to the close proximity of European countries. No other countries used rail/bus as business travel.

Unit:
Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying unit: KM travelled.

Description: Emissions related to employee commuting to/from home and office are estimated using average KM commute by employee per typical working day, mode of transport and country, based on internal employee surveys which had a 25% response rate. 
QBE estimation is based on the following employee survey data for the major countries of operation:

Average daily KM commute:
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ 22KM daily commute in Australia.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ 16KM daily commute in United States of America.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ 28KM in United Kingdom; and
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ 17KM in the Philippines.

Mode of commute transport:
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Australia - 22% car, 17% bus, 42% train, 19% bike, walk or other.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ United States of America 40% car, 10% public transport, and 50% bike, walk or other.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ United Kingdom 64% travelled by train, 3% bus, 20% car and 13% bike, walk or other.
* Philippines - 54% bus/jeepney, 14% motorbike, 22% car, 10% bike, walk or other.
QBE adopts a hybrid-working model and on a global basis employees are working from home on average 3 days per week and 2 days in the office. The averages used in the emissions calculation are on a country-by-country basis which can differ to the global average.

Emissions estimation is based on the following formula:
FTE per country x average number of days working in the office per country x average KM daily commute per working day per country x average percentage of transport mode x DEFRA emission factor for each travel type. 

Scope: Group consolidated entities. Excluding associates/joint venture where QBE does not have operational control.

Unit: Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying activity unit Ã¢ÂÂ KM travelled.

Unnamed: 3: Category 8 Ã¢ÂÂ Upstream leased assets\n(not applicable)
Unnamed: 6:
All the emissions related to leased offices are reported in:
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Scope 1 Ã¢ÂÂ direct stationary energy gas emissions, 
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Scope 2 Ã¢ÂÂ purchased electricity, 
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Scope 2 Ã¢ÂÂ purchased heat and 
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Scope 3 Category upstream fuel and energy related activities.

Therefore, no emissions related to leased offices are included in Category 8 Upstream leased assets.

Unnamed: 3: Category 9 Ã¢ÂÂ Downstream transportation and distribution\n(not applicable)
Unnamed: 6: These are emissions related to downstream transportation and distribution of products sold between the reporting companyÃ¢ÂÂs operations and the end consumer. QBE is an insurance company and Scope 3 Ã¢ÂÂ Category 9 Downstream transportation and distribution is not applicable to QBEÃ¢ÂÂs operations.

Unnamed: 3: Category 10 Ã¢ÂÂ Processing of sold products (not applicable)
Unnamed: 6: These are emissions related to processing of intermediate products sold by downstream companies. QBE is an insurance company and Scope 3 Ã¢ÂÂ Category 10 Processing of Sold Products does not apply to QBE operations.

Unnamed: 3: Category 11 Ã¢ÂÂ Use of sold products (not applicable)
Unnamed: 6: These are emissions related to the end use of goods and services sold by the reporting company. QBE is an insurance company and Scope 3 Ã¢ÂÂ Category 11 Use of Sold Products does not apply to QBE operations.

Unnamed: 3: Category 12 Ã¢ÂÂ End-of-life treatment of sold products \n(not applicable)
Unnamed: 6: These are emissions related to waste disposal and treatment of products sold by the reporting company at the end of their life. QBE is an insurance company and Scope 3 Ã¢ÂÂ Category 12 End-of-life treatment of Sold Products does not apply to QBE operations.

Unnamed: 4: Energy usage from buildings that QBE sublet
Unnamed: 6:
Description: Emissions from energy usage of buildings that QBE owned/leased and sublet. 

Emissions from electricity purchased are measured as:
(i) Australia Ã¢ÂÂ kWh energy used, multiplied by the NGER purchased electricity emission factor
(ii) United States - kWh energy used, multiplied by the eGRID energy emission factor.
(iii) Other countries/regions Ã¢ÂÂ kWh energy used, multiplied by the International Energy Agency (IEA) country emission factors
The kWh energy used would be offset by any GreenPower renewable electricity contracts purchased.

Scope: Only North America has buildings that QBE owned and sublet. All other offices are leased offices.

Unit:
Emissions unit: tCO2e.
Underlying activity unit Ã¢ÂÂ kWh electricity purchased

These are emissions related to operation of franchises not included in Scope 1 and Scope 2 and reported by franchisor. QBE is not a franchise company and therefore Scope 3 Ã¢ÂÂ Category 14 Franchisees does not apply to QBE operations.

Unnamed: 4: Investment emissions \n(reported separately - not included in operational scope 3 inventory)
Unnamed: 6: Description: Attributed emissions related to QBE's investments portfolio. QBE joined the UN-convened Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA) in 2021. QBE adopted the investment emissions methodology approved by the NZAOA, which is guided by the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF) financed emissions methodology.\n\nInvestment emissions are not included in the operational Scope 3 inventory presented in the data book.

Unnamed: 2: Focus area 2: Enable a sustainable and resilient workforce

Unnamed: 6: The distribution of employees by gender as at 31 December 2023 as self-recorded in the HR system of record. Includes workers employed on either a full-time or part-time basis as permanent or fixed-term employees; excludes contractors and temporary employees.\n

The distribution of employees by division as at 31 December 2023. Includes workers employed on either a full-time or part-time basis as permanent or fixed-term employees; excludes contractors and temporary employees.\n

Unnamed: 4: Workforce (%) by employment level and gender
Unnamed: 6: The percentage of employees by job level (GEC to level 6) and gender as at 31 December 2023. Includes workers employed on either a full-time or part-time basis as permanent or fixed-term employees; excludes contractors and temporary employees, and excludes persons whose gender is unspecified in the system of record. When breaking down by gender, unspecified is not shown as a separate category as it represents individuals where the field has not been populated.\n\nAt QBE, employee level is determined by role, responsibilities and level of experience required and is maintained in our HR system Workday. Employment Level is a classification scale of all job roles, using a 0 through 6 scale, whereby Level 0 encompasses the most senior leadership roles (i.e., GEC), and Level 6 encompasses the most junior entry-level roles.
